awd_titl_txt: REU Site: A Convergent Approach on Traineeship Towards Realizing H2 Economy
awd_abstract_narration:
This new Research Experience for Undergraduate Students (REU) Site will initiate a cohesive program at the Center for Clean Energy Engineering (C2E2) and the School of Engineering at the University of Connecticut (UCONN) to engage talented minority and underrepresented undergraduate participants in research on hydrogen (H2) technologies. The program will offer a diverse cohort of undergraduate students the opportunity to engage in research to advance multidisciplinary approaches needed to address national emerging challenges in H2 production, storage and utilization for the development of a sustainable energy future. C2E2 in collaboration with a diverse group of academic and industrial partners will build and invest into the training of young engineers and provide them with the necessary tools to achieve society’s transition to the H2 economy. More than ten faculty members from various departments at the School of Engineering and the School of Law at UCONN will provide integrated education, training, and hands-on interdisciplinary research opportunities that spark the imagination of students towards an exceptional STEM workforce of future engineers.

This three-year interdisciplinary REU Site at UCONN will mentor and train a total of 30 undergraduate students in H2 related technologies. The students will participate directly in research with clear contributions to addressing challenges in development of H2 technologies. Two unique elements of this REU Site are the active engagement of industrial partners and the integration of environmental policy and law. The core objectives of this REU site are: (i) Increase the quantity and quality of scientists and engineers prepared to address challenges on H2 technologies; (ii) Increase the number of students pursuing graduate education and careers in academic or industrial research in H2 related fields; and (iii) Build alliances to enable a sustainable network of students who will become leaders in H2 related fields. In addition to active research projects, students will participate in career development seminars, which will involve fundamentals and technical aspects of H2 technologies, environmental policies and law and real-world industrial practice.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
Our 10-week summer H2-REU program has made a significant impact over the three years, successfully hosting 31 undergraduate students from various backgrounds, universities and community colleges in the US and fostering excellence in hydrogen technologies research. Under the guidance of an interdisciplinary faculty team from the College of Engineering (COE) at the University of Connecticut (UConn), students engaged in cutting-edge research spanning hydrogen production, storage, and utilization technologies. The program's strength laid in its interdisciplinary approach, bringing together faculty expertise from Materials Science, Chemical Engineering, Mechanical Engineering, and Electrical Engineering departments within COE. This collaborative framework provided students with comprehensive exposure to various aspects of hydrogen technology research and development.

Professional development formed a cornerstone of the program, with students participating in numerous enrichment opportunities. Advanced hydrogen technology seminars at the Center for Clean Energy (C2E2) featured distinguished speakers from key organizations including the Connecticut Green Bank, Public Utilities Regulatory Authority (PURA), and Connecticut Center for Advanced Technologies (CCAT). These sessions provided valuable insights into the future of hydrogen technologies and their role in sustainable energy systems.

The program's commitment to comprehensive professional growth was further enhanced through career development workshops conducted by UConn's Career Development Center, complemented by sessions on inclusion, diversity, and equity led by the Vergnano Institute for Inclusion at UConn. To bridge academic research with industry applications, students gained valuable real-world perspective through visits to leading hydrogen technology companies, including HyAxiom, Mott Corporation, and Nel Hydrogen.

Academic excellence was fostered through collaborative learning initiatives, including writing and reading clubs where students shared their experiences and documented their technical findings. These activities strengthened both their research capabilities and their ability to communicate complex technical concepts effectively. The program also recognized the importance of community building, incorporating social activities such as trivia events, ice cream socials, and campus BBQ gatherings, which helped create a friendly atmosphere and strong peer relationships.

Each year the program finished with a comprehensive research presentation session where students showcased their findings to the participating faculty. These presentations demonstrated not only the technical depth of their research but also their growth as emerging scholars in the field of hydrogen technologies. Throughout the program, students developed valuable technical expertise while building professional networks and gaining insights into career opportunities in sustainable energy. The results obtained during the H2-REU program, as well as the presentation skills learned from the participating students, have been highly regarded at major conferences, such as AIChE Annual Student Conference. The presented research has been prized with two awards: “1st Place Overall Environmental Division” and 1st Place Environmental Division I”- 2023 AIChE Annual Student Conference, Orlando, FL.

This H2-REU program successfully achieved its goals by combining rigorous research experience with professional development, industry exposure, and community building. The result was a well-rounded educational experience that prepared students for future careers in hydrogen technologies and academic research, while contributing to the advancement of sustainable energy solutions. Many of the H2-REU students who participated in this program have been inspired to pursue with graduate schools in STEM programs at various universities across the country.
